[kafka-trunk-git-pr #313](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/313/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
@gwenshap @junrao @guozhangwang pinging for review

How will we update the docs in the kafka-site repository? Is the idea to copy manually from this one? If so, it would be good to document this somewhere (maybe the wiki?) so that it's clear what the plan is.

Thanks for the PR. There is a PR open for upgrading to zkclient 0.6 (https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/184), which solves this without requiring exclusions. If you agree, please close this PR (we can't do it ourselves).

Yes, that is the plan. We will maintain only  technical doc pages 
(api.html, design.html, ecosystem.html, introduction.html, ops.html, upgrade.html
configuration.html, documentation.html, implementation.html, migration.html
quickstart.html, uses.html)

During release, we need to manually copy these files to a version directory (08X/) inside kafka-site repo and update documentation.html, downloads.html pages in kafka-site repo.

After this PR merge, I will update contributing.html

Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
@ijuma I think ErrorMapping will be eliminated in KAFKA-1929 in favor of the client-side Errors. Until then, @junrao wanted to keep them in sync.
Yes, I understand. I just wasn't clear what it meant to be kept in sync (is it just adding comments as in the PR or to update `exceptionToCode` as well).
Maybe we can hold off on this and I can just knock out KAFKA-1929 instead.
That would be nice. In any case, I did verify that the comments added in the PR are correct. :)

Hi @mpoindexter, I'd like to see this patch fixing the problem finally.
Looks like @asfbot is a bot and won't tell us any details here, more over that their jenkins doesn't keep whole build history. I cannot check what was wrong with that particular build.
Do you have any details as to what exactly has gone wrong?
Was it test failing or a merge conflict (as is usually the case with those jenkins builds)?

It was a test failure (can't remember exactly which test).  I looked at the failing test and it did not seem related to my changes as far as I could tell, and I could not reproduce the test failure in my environment.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #326](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/326/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@ijuma I wrote a very basic unit test to check the acls are correctly set in secure setup. However ZkUtils is an "object" and its isSecure variable is initialized on first reference to ZkUtil. This means if the unit test runs in isolation (in a new JVM) it passes , however if it runs in the same JVM (default gradle behavior to reuse the same jvm for all test cases) as some other unit test depending on the order of execution one of the 2 test case will fail. I can think of 2 alternatives
- Fork a new JVM for each test case. Obvious disadvantage of tests taking longer to run. On my machine it increased the test execution time by 54 seconds (Total time: 5 mins 27.038 secs instead of 
  Total time: 4 mins 21.574 secs).
- Make isSecure a method that dynamically returns true or false and getAcls also dynamically. This has the obvious disadvantage of re parsing the jaas file on each zkUtil call that tries to write something to decide if zookeeper is secured or not which practically should not change in real production.

I also explored if there is a way to reload an object instance but that just seems like an even worst heck. Let me know if you can think of any other less hecky option. 

You can see the actual unit test https://github.com/Parth-Brahmbhatt/kafka/commit/ebedba5629e6253aac7976ed4a0fc1dbde5fffdd 

and the changes to build.gradle to make it spawn one jvm per unit test is https://github.com/Parth-Brahmbhatt/kafka/commit/7f5bba888350f0ae9d8d3878fa0e0016168c2ee5

Hi @ijuma, good question. In fact, I didn't want to create a new Node just to test it, but looking again I should have been done that. Gonna change now. Btw, did you see that `now` is not used by `isReady`?

Ran System Tests also and still passing http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/69/console

@gwenshap I did some detailed testing today using this patch on ec2. I seems ok. Could we commit?

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #327](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/327/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

I've been able to reproduce the timeout locally on a fresh cluster. It appears to be caused by the delay required to create the __consumer_offsets topic. The consumer metadata request currently depends on this topic in order to discover the coordinator of a group. Once it's created, however, I haven't been able to reproduce the timeout.
can you address the questions I posted earlier today?
@becketqin @onurkaraman Could you review the updated patch if you have time? Thanks!
Sounds good. Yes, the mocks often ignore parameters if not needed for the existing tests.
@mpoindexter why not amend this commit (without changing anything) so that a new build is triggered? We will be able see if anything fails in the new build.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #328](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/328/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
@auradkar please, tell me if it's good. Thx!
@ijuma please, tell me if it's good. Thx!
Well, your change looked good, but now I am seeing a number of new commits in this branch? Seems like a merge/rebase gone wrong.
Yeah, has just fixed that. Sorry!
LGTM

@hachikuji Here is summary of changes:

1) Reverted the renaming of function fetchedRecords()
2) Removed no-longer-needed OFFSET_OUT_OF_RANGE in handleFetchResponse()
3) Only throw exception if defaultResetStrategy != None.

Here is the change that you recommended but I haven't made:

1) Clear exception in fetchedRecords() if partitionAssignmentNeeded() == true
2) Store the map and create the exception in fetchedRecords() if the map is not empty

Please let me know if you have any comment on the updated patch. Thanks again for taking time to review the patch!

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #329](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/329/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

Urgh, the failures in the Jenkins build above looks unrelated to my changes (see below):

```
kafka.api.ProducerSendTest > testClose FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Partition [topic,0] metadata not propagated after 5000 ms
        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.waitUntilTrue(TestUtils.scala:655)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.waitUntilMetadataIsPropagated(TestUtils.scala:695)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$$anonfun$createTopic$1.apply(TestUtils.scala:199)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$$anonfun$createTopic$1.apply(TestUtils.scala:198)
        at scala.collection.TraversableLike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(TraversableLike.scala:244)
        at scala.collection.TraversableLike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(TraversableLike.scala:244)
        at scala.collection.immutable.Range.foreach(Range.scala:141)
        at scala.collection.TraversableLike$class.map(TraversableLike.scala:244)
        at scala.collection.AbstractTraversable.map(Traversable.scala:105)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.createTopic(TestUtils.scala:198)
        at kafka.api.ProducerSendTest.testClose(ProducerSendTest.scala:197)
```

So, I am rebasing again. Hope this helps.

Yes your original patch is simpler. We may also want to survey our usage of `schedule` and see if there are places where asynchronously scheduled tasks _need_ to complete before shutdown. (Right now, we would get an `IllegalStateException`)

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #330](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/330/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
I left a few comments, but mostly they were things that could potentially be clarified. Only one question about correctness. After those issues are followed up on, this looks good to me.

Urgh, the tests are failing with non related changes (see below). They pass on my local machine, so I am not sure it is really related to this patch...

```
kafka.server.ReplicaFetchTest > testReplicaFetcherThread FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Partition [foo,0] metadata not propagated after 5000 ms
        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.waitUntilTrue(TestUtils.scala:655)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.waitUntilMetadataIsPropagated(TestUtils.scala:695)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$$anonfun$createTopic$1.apply(TestUtils.scala:199)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$$anonfun$createTopic$1.apply(TestUtils.scala:198)
        at scala.collection.TraversableLike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(TraversableLike.scala:244)
        at scala.collection.TraversableLike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(TraversableLike.scala:244)
        at scala.collection.immutable.Range.foreach(Range.scala:141)
        at scala.collection.TraversableLike$class.map(TraversableLike.scala:244)
        at scala.collection.AbstractTraversable.map(Traversable.scala:105)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.createTopic(TestUtils.scala:198)
        at kafka.server.ReplicaFetchTest$$anonfun$testReplicaFetcherThread$2.apply(ReplicaFetchTest.scala:55)
        at kafka.server.ReplicaFetchTest$$anonfun$testReplicaFetcherThread$2.apply(ReplicaFetchTest.scala:54)
        at scala.collection.immutable.List.foreach(List.scala:318)
        at kafka.server.ReplicaFetchTest.testReplicaFetcherThread(ReplicaFetchTest.scala:54)
```

Did a rebase just in case it helps.

@ewencp I think @granders said he thought there were cases he was seeing timeouts where this wouldn't have been an issue, so I was going to wait to see what he could find. The option I discussed with him was to use the poll(0) trick to ensure that the assignment is active before beginning the consume loop. The better solution would probably be to combine waitUntil and the rebalance callback to get the same effect.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #334](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/334/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@hachikuji Yeah, I wanted to make sure we have a good solution for this because it's actually a pretty big usability issue for the new consumer, in my opinion. The poll(0) trick works, but a) isn't great since poll(0) shouldn't actually block anyway (if we fix timeouts on most things, this won't really work anymore) and b) requires every app that actually writes real tests to do the same thing because in all likelihood, if they perform an integration or system test, they'll be working with a fresh cluster.
